March 10th Democrat Primary Results for 6 states including Michigan due today
content:
The results of the Democrat Primaries in 6 states will be released today where a total of 352 delegates will be up for grabs and will be keenly eyed to see if Bernie Sanders can resist his campaign being steamrolled by former VP Biden who is coming off a decisive win from last week’s Super Tuesday primaries.

States (delegates): Michigan (125), Washington (89), Missouri (68), Mississippi (36), Idaho (20), North Dakota (14)

Michigan is seen as the key battle state as it has the most delegates of those being contended today, while Sanders has labelled it as the most important state for him which he surprisingly won in 2016 against Hillary Clinton despite underperforming in polls, while recent polls also have him trailing Biden 53.6% vs. 32.3% for the state.

The polls are due to close from 2000EDT/0000GMT although there had been prior warnings of a delay in Michigan results.

Biden is viewed the most market friendly outcome given his mainstream agenda as was evident following his Super Tuesday victory which spurred risk appetite especially in the healthcare sector, although some have previously argued that Sanders would be an easier opponent for President Trump and increases the likelihood of a continuation of the political status quo.

Current delegate count: Biden (670), Sanders (574)

Total delegates: 3979; Minimum delegates needed to win nomination: 1991

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US CDC reported coronavirus cases rose to 696 (Prev. 462) and the death toll was at 25 (Prev. 19). (Newswires)

Washington state is mulling mandatory measures to contain the coronavirus, according to Governor Inslee who expects a dramatic rise in cases without "real action". Elsewhere, New York Governor Cuomo is to establish containment area in part of New York suburb (New Rochelle) to stop virus spread and the National Guard will be deployed in containment area which is last two weeks including school closures. (Newswires)

Italy’s total coronavirus cases rose to 10,149 (Prev. 9172) and the death toll increased to 631 from Prev. 463. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte called on the ECB to do whatever it takes with the need for a coordinated monetary and fiscal response, while it was also reported that Italy is discussing stimulus package as much as EUR 16bln and raising the deficit target to just under 3%. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

BoJ bought JPY 101.4bln of ETFs for the 4th occasion this month and are reportedly mulling the expansion of ETF purchase program. There were also reports that Japan’s government plans to spend JPY 430.8bln in another stimulus package to deal with the economic fallout from the virus outbreak. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

UK Budget is to boost infrastructure spending by GBP 100bln and public sector net investment to rise to 3% of GDP, up from 2.2%. (ITV)

UK PM Johnson expects the next round of Brexit negotiations to go ahead as plans and there are no contingency measures in place, while he added we are clear what we want to achieve in negotiations. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson spokesman commented regarding Huawei stating that the government wants to get to a place where there are no high-risk vendors involve and will keep 35% cap under review. (Newswires)

EU Commission Head Von Der Leyen said EU executives will set up an investment fund from the coronavirus which will reach EUR 25bln and will release EUR 7.5bln for the fund, while she stated that there will be guidelines by the end of the week on the flexile use of fiscal and subsidy rules. (Newswires)

Germany is reportedly weighing bank capital reliefs to counter the impact from coronavirus. (Newswires)

  • EU GDP Revised (Q4) Q/Q 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires)
  • EU GDP Revised (Q4) Y/Y 1.0% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 0.9%)
  • EU Employment Final (Q4) Q/Q 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.3%, Rev. 0.2%)
  • EU Employment Final (Q4) Y/Y 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.0%, Rev. 1.1%)

 

FX

Eskom are to extend South Africa's rolling blackouts to Stage 4 as of 12:00 GMT on Tuesday, after a Koeberg nuclear plant unit tripped. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES 

Russian Energy Ministry called a meeting with Russian oil Co's for tomorrow and expect the Energy Ministry to discuss future co-operation with OPEC, according to sources. There were also reports the Kremlin said it is possible when asked if there was any chance of Saudi and Russia returning to OPEC discussions and stated that volatility via the oil price crash will likely continue for a while but this was expected and accounted for. (Newswires)

Iraq oil minister said he is in contact with other OPEC+ members to discuss ways to stop the collapse in oil prices. (Newswires)

US is reportedly postponing sales from their strategic petroleum reserve which was scheduled to be for 12mln barrels. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks +6.4mln (exp. +2.3mln, prev. +1.7mln). (Newswires)

Turkish President Erdogan said he asked Russian President Putin to mutually manage oil fields in Syria's Deir Al Zor, which Putin is reportedly evaluating, while he also could make the same offer to the US. Erdogan also said the US is softening its stance on the purchase of US patriot systems and that the US asked Turkey to guarantee that it will not activate the Russian system. (Newswires)

 

US 

White House is likely to pursue Federal aid for shale companies that are hit by the virus and oil shock. (Washington Post)

US President Trump said he had a great meeting with Republicans on Capitol Hill and that they are working hard on a lot of things but offered no details on stimulus plans, while he told Republican Senators that he wants the payroll tax waived through the election. (Newswires)

US President Trump reportedly told GOP senators two options from the COVID-19 relief plan would be to waive payroll tax through year end or to make the tax cut permanent, according to a source. There were also reports that US President Trump and advisers are considering using the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) as a vehicle to deliver funds to stimulate the economy against mounting damage from the coronavirus - one of the options under review. (Newswires/NYT)

US Republican Senator Rubio said scope of payroll tax cuts being considered for COVID-19 relief could be around USD 300bln, while Republican sources said payroll tax cut discussions have fallen flat and senators were reportedly "far from united" as administration plans are still in the concept phase, according to WaPo reporter. (Newswires/Washington Post)

US Senate Republican McConnell said Treasury Secretary Mnuchin is to meet with House Speaker Pelosi on Tuesday and hopes to see a bipartisan agreement on relief package pretty soon. (Newswires)

There were earlier reports the White House was not ready to roll out specific economic proposals in its response to the widening impact of the coronavirus outbreak, according to admin officials. (CNBC)

 

MARKET RECAP

Markets staged a rebound from yesterday’s heavy sell-off as US President Trump stated he is considering cutting or postponing payroll tax, alongside suggestions Saudi and Russia could meet soon. The announcement aided a risk on environment throughout the EU session and saw ES (H0) futures hit limit up, prior to the US cash open. However, gains reversed as CNBC reported the White House is not ready to roll out specific economic proposals in response to the coronavirus, where inside officials were stunned by his announcement. Although, in flip-flop trade, risk assets caught a bid in the final hour of cash trade as US President Trump emerged from a meeting with Capitol Hill and seems as if he is to continue pushing for a payroll tax cut/deferral, meanwhile both Democrats and Republicans agreed on the urgency for a bipartisan agreement, however some senators held mixed opinions on the economic stimulus package. Energy stocks (XOP, XLE) found a rebound with oil prices following the turmoil on Monday, participants are still generally cautious on the group given the demand and supply backdrop, however. The move higher in yields also sore somewhat of a rebound in Financials (BKX, XLF), although strength was faded somewhat. Tesla (TSLA) and Wynn (WYNN) were some of the names that spiked higher on the open amid reprieve from recent selling – note Tesla also announced the production of its one millionth car. SPX +4.9% at 2882, NDX +5.3% at 8372, DJI +4.9% at 25018.

The TPLEX bear steepened amid a (dead-cat?) bounce back in the equity complex, although yields were off their highs by settlement in another wide-ranging day, particularly in the long-end. Note that US equity futures hit their 5% limit ups in the pre-market alongside rising rates, before drifting lower, which Treasuries found a bid on the back of, as desks noted real money behind equity and oil sales. However, the risk aversion found its limit at the tail-end of European trade and yields then rose again, although not as high as earlier in the session. Note that there was some knee-jerk selling pressure in the belly of the curve after the 3-year Treasury auction tailed by 2.7bps, with a weaker than average B/C ratio, seeing Dealers takedown a larger than usual portion of the offering – coming ahead of the 10-year and 30-year auctions on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively. By settlement, the 2-year yield had risen 15bps, 10-year yield +25bps, and 30-year yield +30bps. US T-note futures (H0) settled 1 point 24 ticks lower at 137-17+.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 10th MARCH 2020: Risk appetite rebounds amid US stimulus hopes
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Crude up, Dollar up.
  • REAR VIEW: Trump discusses payroll tax cut/deferral, hopes of Saudi/Russia convening, Monday’s moves pare back somewhat
  • COMING UP: Data: UK GDP (Estimate), Industrial & Manufacturing Output, US CPI. Events: EIA STEO, OPEC Monthly Report, UK Budget Unveiled. Speakers: Incoming BoE Governor Bailey. Supply: Germany & US. Earnings: Adidas.

* MARKET WRAP: Markets staged a rebound from yesterday’s heavy sell-off as US President Trump stated he is considering cutting or postponing payroll tax, alongside suggestions Saudi and Russia could meet soon. The announcement aided a risk on environment throughout the EU session and saw ES (H0) futures hit limit up, prior to the US cash open. However, gains reversed as CNBC reported the White House is not ready to roll out specific economic proposals in response to the coronavirus, where inside officials were stunned by his announcement. Although, in flip-flop trade, risk assets caught a bid in the final hour of cash trade as US President Trump emerged from a meeting with Capitol Hill and seems as if he is to continue pushing for a payroll tax cut/deferral, meanwhile both Democrats and Republicans agreed on the urgency for a bipartisan agreement, however some senators held mixed opinions on the economic stimulus package. Sources stated the two options would be to waive the payroll tax through to year-end or to make the cut permanent.  Energy prices saw a slight reversal from yesterday with Brent around USD 37/bbl at settlement from lows yesterday of USD 31.02/bbl as OPEC delegates downplay the Saudi v Russia price war, reassuring us it is still too early to give up the alliance. The energy rebound saw an initial 20-30% gain in the worst-hit energy names yesterday (OXY, MRO), however on the open the gains slumped, and MRO headed back towards unchanged levels. The Treasury curve saw yields rise, albeit off highs, with the 30-year reclaiming the 1% figure, however, the rest of the curve remains well beneath. DXY benefitted from the overnight trump comments although remains off highs heading into Asia trade with participants eyeing a 17:30 ET press briefing from VP Pence for any potential details on the potential tax cuts/deferral.

* WTI (J0) SETTLED USD 3.23 HIGHER AT USD 34.66/BBL; BRENT (K0) SETTLED USD 2.86 HIGHER AT USD 37.22/BBL: Energy prices overnight experienced some underlying support from OPEC delegates downplaying the expanding rift between Saudi and Russia, as they noted it is too early to give up on the alliance. That being said, Saudi Aramco’s CEO stated that it will supply its customers with 12.3mln BPD of oil starting April 1st – a number higher than the touted step-by-step increase as per sources, which noted the Kingdom could raise output to 11mln BPD before further ramping production. As such, energy futures came under belated pressure at the time. Contracts then found mild reprieve amidst comments from the Russian Energy Minister who noted Moscow does not rule out join action with OPEC, despite also stating that Russian companies may boost oil output by up to 300k BPD and has potential to increase by 500k BPD – in fitting with comments from Russia’s Rosneft yesterday. Novak also noted of the next joint meeting to take place in May/June; OPEC’s website has scheduled this for June 10th. Shortly after, Saudi Energy Minister said he fails to see the wisdom in holding the OPEC meeting in June only to demonstrate failures in dealing with the ongoing crisis. Russia’s Kremlin remained optimistic and noted that a return to OPEC discussions with Saudi is still a possibility and noted volatility in oil prices will likely continue for a while, but this was expected and accounted for. Sources also stated that the Russian Energy Ministry has called a meeting with Russian oil companies for Wednesday which is expected to discuss future co-operation with OPEC, timings unknown. Amidst the backdrop of an OPEC+ break-up, the Iraq oil minister stated that he is in contact with other OPEC+ members to discuss ways to stop the collapse in oil prices. The weekly US energy inventories would normally draw investors’ attention, although given the environment, are unlikely to cause much stir, nonetheless, the private inventory report is due later on Tuesday ahead of the EIA release on Wednesday, current expectations (bbls) see crude stocks +2.3mln, gasoline -2.5mln and distillates -1.9mln.

* COVID-19 RESPONSE: The White House is not ready to roll out specific economic proposals in its response to the widening impact of the coronavirus outbreak, according to admin officials cited by CNBC, which put pressure on risk assets. CNBC noted that a lot will depend on how the administration’s ideas were digested by Senate Republicans at their meeting on the Hill on Tuesday, where its possible details could be revealed at 17:30 EDT in the Task Force, although highlighted that anything involving spending or taxes will require congressional action, thus removing the immediacy of such policy. Note that Trump briefly spoke to reporters after the meeting and failed to provide any details, resorting to rhetoric that the meeting was “great” and work was being done. President Trump said overnight that he will speak about possible payroll tax relief with Congress and is working with industries including airline and cruise ship industries. However, an NY Times report suggested that Trump and advisers are considering using, as just one option under review, the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) as a vehicle to deliver funds to stimulate the economy. A WSJ reporter also said the administration has been discussing a possible 90-day suspension of payroll tax. Meanwhile as the outbreak deepens in the US, NY Governor Cuomo announced the establishment of a containment area in part of the New York suburb, New Rochelle, to stop the virus spread, where National Guard will be deployed in the area which will last two weeks, including school closures. Furthermore, Washington state is mulling mandatory measures to contain COVID-19, according to Governor Inslee, who expects a dramatic rise in cases without "real action". In Europe, ECB President Lagarde demanded an imminent fiscal reaction in her call with EU leaders, meanwhile EU Commission Chief Von Der Leyen stated an investment fund will be set up to tackle the virus, which will see as much as EUR 25bln. Over in France, President Macron stated EU leaders agreed to take all measures required to avoid instability and a spokesperson noted the EU budgetary measures are needed in response to the coronavirus and the EU must give signal it is ready to act and that a response cannot only be a monetary one. German Parliament is to reportedly make up to EUR 1bln in additional funds available for the coronavirus, according to DPA News citing the CDU head, meanwhile separate reports suggested Germany is weighing bank capital reliefs. Italy has reportedly suspended payments on mortgages across the whole country and is looking at a EUR 16bln stimulus package and raising the deficit target to just under 3%, from 2.2%; sources last night suggested it could be increased to 2.8%.

* CASE UPDATE: US CDC reported 696 cases (prev. 462), 25 deaths (prev. 19) - as of March 9th at 16:00. Italian death toll rises to 631 from 463 on Monday; total cases at 10,149 (prev. 9172). Spain reports 1622 total coronavirus cases (prev. 1204).

* UK BUDGET PREVIEW: Ever since gaining a commanding 80-seat majority in the December 2019 election, expectations have mounted over the government opening-up the spending taps to help boost investment post-Brexit. However, the recent outbreak of COVID19 has shifted the UK fiscal outlook and as such, this week’s update from newly-appointed Chancellor Sunak will likely be geared more towards tackling the fallout of the virus. Note, the budget will be presented on Wednesday alongside a limited set of OBR forecasts, with an additional set of OBR forecasts to be published on Friday. Click here for full preview.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 1 POINT 24 TICKS LOWER AT 137-17+. The TPLEX bear steepened amid a (dead-cat?) bounce back in the equity complex, although yields were off their highs by settlement in another wide-ranging day, particularly in the long-end. Note that US equity futures hit their 5% limit ups in the pre-market alongside rising rates, before drifting lower, which Treasuries found a bid on the back of, as desks noted real money behind equity and oil sales. However, the risk aversion found its limit at the tail-end of European trade and yields then rose again, although not as high as earlier in the session. Note that there was some knee-jerk selling pressure in the belly of the curve after the 3-year Treasury auction tailed by 2.7bps, with a weaker than average B/C ratio, seeing Dealers takedown a larger than usual portion of the offering – coming ahead of the 10-year and 30-year auctions on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively. By settlement, the 2-year yield had risen 15bps, 10-year yield +25bps, and 30-year yield +30bps.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +3.6% at 2845, NDX +3.96% at 8263, DJI +3.5% at 24,684; SECTORS: Technology +6.6%, Financials +6%, Consumer Discretionary +5.4%, Industrials +5.2%, Real Estate +5%, Energy +5%, Communication Svs. +4.53%, Materials +3.9%, Health Care +3.5%, Consumer Staples +2.9%, Utilities +1%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Energy stocks (XOP, XLE) found a rebound with oil prices following the turmoil on Monday, participants are still generally cautious on the group given the demand and supply backdrop, however. The move higher in yields also sore somewhat of a rebound in Financials (BKX, XLF), although strength was faded somewhat. Tesla (TSLA) and Wynn (WYNN) were some of the names that spiked higher on the open amid reprieve from recent selling – note Tesla also announced the production of its one millionth car. Cypress Semiconductor (CY) surged by close to 50% after it passed a US regulatory hurdle for its proposed merger with Infineon (IFX GY). Occidental (OXY) found a second round of strength as investors warmed to it slashing its dividend to USD 0.11/shr from 0.79 as well as cutting its capex guide by a couple of billion. Airlines (AAL, UAL, DAL) were bid following comments from Trump that the administration would be supporting the industry, as well as cruise companies (CCL, RCL, NCLH). Dick’s (DKS) surged after a strong quarter. COVID-19 “beneficiaries” (ZM, GILD, VZ, WMT, CLX, PTON) were offered as participants pared recent moves somewhat.

* NORGES BANK Q1 REGIONAL NETWORK REPORT: Typically, the survey is heavily incorporated in the next Norges Bank rate decision which is on March 19th. However, while the remarks are still of note the main survey period being January 27th to February 14th makes them less so; as the period will not entirely incorporate the scale of the coronavirus. Nonetheless, the Networks contacts highlight that activity growth has continued to decline throughout winter and they expect growth to continue to drop for the next 6-months. More notably, the Bank elected to undertake an additional phone survey between March 4th-6th which is not included in the published figures, in this additional survey the latest information is suggesting that the virus will weigh on activity in the Norwegian business sector ahead; with a third of participants revising their growth outlook down in recent weeks. Looking ahead to next week’s rate decision, where a number of banks have recently changed their call from an unchanged meeting to a cut, given the ongoing headwinds the virus presents, soft domestic CPI in February which is in contrast to January’s surprisingly strong number and the knock-on impact of the recent sell-off in oil prices. Note, currently the Norges Bank’s rate path sees the rate left unchanged at 1.5% for the entirety of the period; albeit, with a very mild hiking bias incorporated.

* FX WRAP: The dollar saw hefty gains today following the prior day sell off taking its cues from stimulus package ideas, higher yields and an outflow of havens (JPY, CHF) as markets saw a risk-friendly tone; a bounce from yesterday’s decline. USDJPY reclaimed 105.50 from lows of 102, meanwhile, EURCHF reclaimed 1.06, just. XAU also saw the same direction as other havens amid the improved risk appetite which saw the precious metal consolidate around the 1650 handle heading into overnight trade. GBP traded lower ahead of the budget tomorrow, meanwhile EUR took ques from a firmer dollar; Italy cases continue to rocket. AUD & NZD lower against the buck with the former undermined by a downbeat NAB business survey, meanwhile NZD likely impacted by dovish commentary from Governor Orr who suggested negative rates or ZIRP cannot be ruled out, noting the steps being considered includes forward guidance, negative rates and rates swaps. However, the Governor noted zero bound for rates is far from the most likely outcome. EMFX was generally firmer across the board in a reversal from yesterday’s price action. RUB retraced some of the heavy declines from Monday as oil saw a bounce while the CBR announced pre-emptive measures where it will sell foreign currency to lower market volatility and it will conduct RUB 500bln worth of repo operations and increase currency swap operations limit to USD 5bln today. KRW also firmer as it takes measures to fight off the coronavirus where the BoK noted it will actively use all available tools to stabilise markets, noting it is paying close attention to FX, adding it will use loans and open market operations to support SME’s.

subject: WTI (J0) settled USD 3.23 higher at USD 34.66/bbl; Brent (K0) settles USD 2.86 higher at USD 37.22/bbl
analysis_details: • Energy prices overnight experienced some underlying support from OPEC delegates downplaying the expanding rift between Saudi and Russia, as they noted it is too early to give up on the alliance. That being said, Saudi Aramco’s CEO stated that it will supply its customers with 12.3mln BPD of oil starting April 1st – a number higher than the touted step-by-step increase as per sources, which noted the Kingdom could raise output to 11mln BPD before further ramping production. As such, energy futures came under belated pressure at the time. Contracts then found mild reprieve amidst comments from the Russian Energy Minister who noted Moscow does not rule out join action with OPEC, despite also stating that Russian companies may boost oil output by up to 300k BPD and has potential to increase by 500k BPD – in fitting with comments from Russia’s Rosneft yesterday. Novak also noted of the next joint meeting to take place in May/June; OPEC’s website has scheduled this for June 10th. Shortly after, Saudi Energy Minister said he fails to see the wisdom in holding the OPEC meeting in June only to demonstrate failures in dealing with the ongoing crisis. Russia’s Kremlin remained optimistic and noted that a return to OPEC discussions with Saudi is still a possibility and noted volatility in oil prices will likely continue for a while, but this was expected and accounted for. Sources also stated that the Russian Energy Ministry has called a meeting with Russian oil companies for Wednesday which is expected to discuss future co-operation with OPEC, timings unknown. Amidst the backdrop of an OPEC+ break-up, the Iraq oil minister stated that he is in contact with other OPEC+ members to discuss ways to stop the collapse in oil prices. The weekly US energy inventories would normally draw investors’ attention, although given the environment, are unlikely to cause much stir, nonetheless, the private inventory report is due later on Tuesday ahead of the EIA release on Wednesday, current expectations (bbls) see crude stocks +2.3mln, gasoline -2.5mln and distillates -1.9mln.

Daily FX Wrap: tentative return to risk following Monday’s mass exodus
content:
DXY

Far from a total or even guaranteed turnaround Tuesday, but market conditions have certainly been less fractious and fragile thus far as crude prices trade within relatively contained Usd3-4.5/brl ranges on the wide vs yesterday’s huge parameters, and mostly downside activity. Hence, broad sentiment has at least stabilised and prompted some degree of normality across the US Treasury (in terms of outright yield and curve profile) to prop up the Greenback alongside rebounds vs safer havens. However, the index has not been able to sustain recovery momentum above 96.000 and from a technical perspective a ‘close’ below 95.879 (minor Fib retracement from 2020 high) would be destructive.

NOK/SEK 

The Scandinavian Crowns are still holding net gains vs G10 rivals, but some distance from best levels as the risk revival runs out of steam, with Eur/Nok nudging back above 10.9000 and Eur/Sek eyeing 10.8000 vs sub-10.7300/10.7200 respectively at one stage. The Norwegian Crown is still being propped by the aforementioned rebound in oil rather than any bearish impulses via hefty CPI misses against consensus and a regional survey flagging downside economic growth and activity, without taking into account the worst of the hit from nCoV. Meanwhile, Riksbank comments continue err on the side of unconventional policy instead of returning to NIRP and little sign on any emergency inter-meeting move.

JPY/GBP/AUD/CHF/NZD/EUR/CAD

The Yen remains the major laggard amidst unwinding safe-haven positioning, albeit well above lows circa 105.25 amidst the late EU wobble in risk, but Cable is now extending its retreat from 1.3200 peaks through 1.2950 on pre-UK budget caution and persistent jitters over the prospect of a hard Brexit. Elsewhere, the Aussie has been undermined by a downbeat NAB business survey and the Franc is caught between pillar and post as a safe-haven prone to SNB intervention next Thursday or before if it becomes more than highly valued in the run up to the next official quarterly policy review. On that note, RBNZ chat about ZIRP or even negative rates as a lower bound in preference to alternative stimulus from Governor Orr have been taken on board by the Kiwi and the Euro awaits this week’s ECB meeting with new Staff forecasts to see what the GC might do to mitigate the growing COVID-19 threat that could be coordinated with EU fiscal measures. Finally on the major stage, an element of stabilisation in crude has cushioned the Loonie from deeper post-BoC rate cut losses and a breach of 1.3700.

EM 

More volatile trade for regional currencies, though not as choppy and ultimately bad as yesterday as the Rouble regains over 3.5% vs the Buck alongside Brent and others are propped by direct intervention. However, the Mxn and Czk are underperforming awaiting a presser from Mexico’s Finance Minister and after the CNB opened the door for a cut in March.

Ever since gaining a commanding 80-seat majority in the December 2019 election, expectations have mounted over the government opening-up the spending taps to help boost investment post-Brexit. However, the recent outbreak of COVID-19 has shifted the UK fiscal outlook and as such, this week’s update from newly-appointed Chancellor Sunak will likely be geared more towards tackling the fallout of the virus. Note, the budget will be presented on Wednesday alongside a limited set of OBR forecasts, with an additional set of OBR forecasts to be published on Friday.

10th March 2020

  • Energy names (XOP, XLE, MRO, APA, OXY…) are finding a bit of a bounce back (as is the wider market) after getting smashed on Monday, where crude oil prices have also found some support on some OPEC reports of it being too early to give up on a Russia-Saudi resolution.

Elsewhere, Wall Street CEOs will meet with the Trump administration at the White House on Wednesday to discuss the economic impact of the virus.
  • JPM on recent market selloff, “Based on history, a market sell-off of this magnitude implies a 65- 75% chance of a recession in the next 12 months. In our view, however, the market has gone ahead and priced in too severe of an adverse scenario, assuming we get timely and strong counter-policy response and a COVID-19 outbreak that peaks in the coming weeks.” The bank also sees potential for a reversal pairs trade of COVID-19 beneficiaries (e.g. ZM, NFLX, WMT, VZ, TGT, CLX).

Newsquawk Central Banks - PREVIEW: ECB policy decision due Thursday 12th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

Surveyed analysts expect the Bank to stand pat on rates this time around, however, market pricing currently assigns a 100% probability of a 10bps reduction to the deposit rate with a further 10bps priced in by September. The meeting takes place against a backdrop of severe economic uncertainty in which the full extent of the COVID-19 outbreak remains unknown. However, containment efforts across the continent have certainly impaired economic activity and as such, heightened calls for stimulus from the Governing Council. It remains to be seen whether the ECB will adopt a wait-and-see approach or unveil supportive measures, which could include rate reductions, expansion of the APP, adjustments to tiering thresholds, sweetening of the terms of existing TLTROs, financing measures for SMEs.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 10th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Risk sentiment remains firmer in EU hours after a strong APAC handover; though the overall narrative hasn’t changed fundamentally
  • DXY is modestly firmer as the JPY retreats in-line with other safe havens
  • President Trump announced he is to hold a press conference today on economic measures to respond to the coronavirus and suggested that economic steps will be major
  • Japan is reportedly planning to spend JPY 430.8bln in second package of steps on virus outbreak; BoJ are considering expanding their ETF purchase programme
  • Saudi Aramco CEO said the Co. will supply customers with 12.3mln BPD in April; Russia Energy Minister Novak says Russian companies may boost oil output by up to 300k BPD
  • RBNZ Governor Orr said they have not and still do not need to use alternative monetary policy instruments
  • Looking ahead highlights include APIs & supply from the US

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Mainland China reported 19 additional coronavirus cases and 17 additional deaths on March 9th vs. Prev. 40 additional cases and 22 additional deaths on March 8th, to bring the total number of cases in China to 80754 and death toll to 3136. (Newswires) Chinese President Xi arrived in Wuhan for the first time following the outbreak, while there were also reports that China’s Hubei province is to implement a health code system to start permitting people to travel within the province. (Newswires)

China says all temporary coronavirus hospitals are now shut, according to state media. (Newswires)

38 out of the 42 Apple (AAPL) stores in Chinese mainland have reopened as of Tuesday as coronavirus outbreak eased, but some with shorter business hours, 3 stores in Tianjin and 1 in Suzhou remain close, according to Global Times. (Twitter)

South Korea coronavirus cases increased by 131 to a total of 7513 and its death toll increased by 3 to a total of 54. Separately, South Korean regulator will ban short selling of overheated stocks for 10 days starting March 11th. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he will speak about possible payroll tax relief with Congress and is working with industries including airline and cruise ship industries. President Trump also announced he is to hold a press conference today on economic measures to respond to the coronavirus and suggested that economic steps will be major, while reports later suggested that the coronavirus aid package will leave out the travel industry for now but will include payroll tax cut and short-term paid sick leave. (Newswires)

Japan is reportedly planning to spend JPY 430.8bln in second package of steps on virus outbreak, according to sources. (Newswires) Prior to this, Japanese Finance Minister Aso said the government is to announce a 2nd package of steps on coronavirus on Tuesday and that G7 agreed to take fiscal and monetary steps as appropriate. There were also later comments from PM Abe who confirmed he will submit an emergency measure package to parliament today and will implement what is needed without hesitation to respond to coronavirus situation, while the second emergency package will include steps related to jobs and small firms. (Newswires) BoJ are reportedly mulling the expansion of ETF purchase program, according to Kyodo. (Kyodo)

England's Deputy Chief Medical Officer said that many thousands of cases of the virus will appear in the UK in due course, according to Sky News. (Sky News)

Head of Germany's Ifo Institute sees recession in Germany due to the virus outbreak and global economy is on the brink of crisis. (Newswires)

Italy's Industry Minister said the government will adopt measures worth EUR 10bln to tackle the virus outbreak. And the government will ask for the review of EU stability pact and fiscal compact rules due to the virus outbreak. (Newswires) 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly higher as markets began to pick up the pieces from the recent oil-triggered devastation, which resulted in losses of over 7% among most major US indices for the worst performance on Wall St. since 2008. Nonetheless, US equity futures found some reprieve overnight despite briefly dipping into bear market territory with the rebound helped by hopes of policy action with President Trump set to discuss payroll tax relief with congress and to hold a press conference on economic measures to respond to the coronavirus which he suggested will be major steps, while Japanese is to submit a 2nd package of steps on coronavirus to parliament. ASX 200 (+3.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) gained in which the former shrugged off opening losses of around 4% led by the recovery in the energy and financials sectors, while the Japanese benchmark also nursed losses helped by favourable currency moves. Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.8%) were initially indecisive after continued PBoC liquidity inaction but eventually surged following a further reduction in China’s additional coronavirus cases and President Xi’s visit to the Wuhan coronavirus epicentre for the first time since the outbreak which was seen to be symbolic of China’s progress in its battle against the epidemic. Finally, 10yr JGBs slipped below 155.00 as it tracked the pullback in USTs after the recent safe-haven surge and as equity markets stabilized, while prices were also pressured after weaker results at the 5yr JGB auction.

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9389 vs. Exp. 6.9562 (Prev. 6.9260). (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position

Chinese CPI (Feb) Y/Y 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.2% (Prev. 5.4%). (Newswires)

Chinese PPI YY (Feb) -0.4% vs. Exp. -0.3% (Prev. 0.1%)

UK/EU

Britain is set to table its plans for a Canada-style free trade agreement with the EU ahead of the next round of negotiations, according to the government. (Times)

Senior Conservative MPs are to back an amendment to end Huawei’s role in the UK’s 5G network; via an amendment to the Telecommunication Infrastructure bill, up to 30 Tory MPs are seen backing the bill. (BBC)

UK BRC Sales Like-For-Like (Feb) Y/Y -0.4% (Prev. 0.0%). (Newswires)

Barclaycard said UK consumer spending rose 2.2% Y/Y in Feb. vs. 3.9% Y/Y increase in January, while it added that coronavirus fears led to 28% of respondents avoiding the high street and other busy places. (Newswires)

Discussions between Turkish President Erdogan and the EU regarding a resolution to the ongoing refugee crisis ended without an agreement on Monday. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European stocks consolidate [Eurostoxx 50 +4.0%] following the prior session’s detrimental sell-off sparked by further coronavirus woes and considerable downside in energy markets. Overnight, APAC bourses reflected a similarly conciliatory tone as stocks recovered following a mixed open – with desks pointing to hopes of US stimulus announcements in the form of payroll tax relief. European bourses got off to a shaky start with futures erasing a chunk of its overnight gains ahead of the cash open before reversing course to fresh session highs at the time of writing. The Italian bourse is conforming to the broad gains in the region despite Italy’s country-wide lockdown. The index remains buoyed by a raft of Italian stimulus including a ramp-up in measures to EUR 10bln from EUR 7.5bln. Meanwhile, sectors trade in positive territory and reflect a “risk-on” mood as cyclicals fare better than defensive. The energy sector outperforms following the prior session’s hefty losses and as the oil complex rebounds, with similar action seen in financials. Stoxx 600 movers largely reflect an inverse of yesterday. Oil giants Shell (+12.5%), Total (+9.0%) and BP (+8.5%) amongst the top gainers. On that front, Exane BNP remains of the view that cash dividends will continue to see support despite yesterday’s sharp sell-off in oil and energy names, with preferred names remaining BP, Total and Equinor. In terms of more micro-movers, Deutsche Post (+6.3%) shares are supported amid an increase in YY Q4 revenue and a reaffirmance of its 2022 guidance. Italian-listed Diasorin (+17.4%) rose to the top of the FTSE MIB as the Co. completed its studies regarding a launch of coronavirus tests by end-March.

FX

NOK/JPY - Still flanking the G10 ranks, but the Norwegian Krona is now in pole position and Yen at the back of the pack in contrast to Monday when oil prices were tanking and risk aversion rife. Eur/Nok has recoiled further from nigh on 11.0000 to sub-10.7550 at one stage and almost oblivious to significantly weaker than expected inflation data or a downbeat regional survey even before the full extent of the coronavirus contagion has been taken into consideration. Conversely, Usd/Jpy has rebounded from near 101.00 yesterday to just over 105.00 as broad sentiment stabilises alongside crude, despite more exchanges between Saudi Arabia and Russia on the supply front.

USD - The Dollar has benefited from the relative calm in financial markets, partly instilled by US pledges via President Trump and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin to unveil big fiscal support measures, which in turn have flipped Treasuries back into bear steepening mode and eroded some appeal from safer currency and other havens. Hence, the DXY has pared losses from yesterday’s new 94.650 ytd base and briefly topped 96.000 within a 96.006-95.199 range.

CHF/EUR/GBP/NZD/AUD - All softer vs the Greenback due to the aforementioned turnaround in mood from extreme depression, with the Franc below 0.9300 again, Euro sub-1.1400, Cable under 1.3100 and Antipodeans losing a degree of their yield appeal from 0.6600+ and 0.6350+ respectively overnight. The Aussie also had drops in NAB business conditions and confidence to digest, while the Kiwi is absorbing comments from RBNZ Governor Orr indicating that there is more room to reduce the OCR (to zero or even negative if needed) rather than resorting to unconventional policy easing.

CAD/SEK -The Loonie is deriving some comfort from oil finding a base (for the time being at least) between 1.3706-1.3608 extremes vs its US counterpart and the Swedish Crown has regrouped amidst more Riksbank guidance steering away from a reversal in the repo rate in favour of QE if it need to take emergency policy action. Eur/Sek hovering around 10.7200 from 10.8100+ earlier and like the Nok cross not unduly bothered about data (household consumption).

EM - Respite after the rout, and with the Rouble not just gleaning traction from Brent clawing back outsize declines, but also the CBR’s intervention to stop the Rub depreciating in line with other regional Central Banks and bodies attempting to stem the tide.

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Feb) -4 (Prev. -1). (Newswires) Australian NAB Business Conditions (Feb) 0 (Prev. 3)

RBNZ Governor Orr said they have not and still do not need to use alternative monetary policy instruments and they are fortunate to have time to prepare for alternative steps unlike other OECD countries, while he also commented that zero bound for rates is far from most likely outcome but cannot be ruled out and that steps being considered include forward guidance, negative rates and rate swaps. Furthermore, Orr suggested need to be considered and realistic as to how effective rate changes will be in buffering the economy and that they will continue to use conventional policy until it is exhausted such as when OCR reaches 0%. (Newswires)

Norges Bank Regional Network Survey (Q1)

-        Initial Survey (27th Jan to 14th Feb)

o    Regional Network contacts, activity growth has continued to decline through winter

o    Enterprises expect growth to continue to drift down in the next six months. After the ordinary survey, the spread of coronavirus has increased.

o    Weak demand from export markets, lower residential construction activity and reduced retail sales are having a dampening effect on growth.

-        Phone Survey (March 4th – 6th) taken to account for the coronavirus

o    Suggests that the virus outbreak will weigh on activity in the Norwegian business sector ahead.

o    Over 1/3 of enterprises have revised down their growth outlook in recent weeks.

o    Few enterprises are planning workforce reductions, but some mentioned the possibility of layoffs.

Riksbank Remarks before the Riksdag:

-        Governor Ingves: Do not see a lower policy rate as the most important measure at present, assess the balance sheet should not be reduced in the coming year. Spread of the virus will have effect on the economy, but too early to determine the magnitude. Could be more generous terms for loans to banks and/or direct purchases of securities; assessment right now is that maintaining the supply of liquidity is the most important thing.

-        Breman: Confident we can act to stabilise the Swedish economy, toolbox can be used in full. Measures taken will depend on the situation; opportunities to counteract a decline in the Swedish economy will also improve when several policy areas make a contribution. Adds, Riksbank’s actions are not automatically influenced by actions by other central banks; one option would be to lend to Co's via banks rather than purchasing corporate bonds

Russian Central Bank says will sell foreign currency from today to lower market volatility, will conduct RUB 500bln repo operations, will increase currency swap operations limit to USD 5bln today, moves are pre-emptive measures. (Newswires)

FIXED

Rather mixed UK auction results have not really altered the current trend of core debt unwinding more of Monday’s huge safe-haven gains and yield compression amidst long end outperformance in recognition of the general revival in risk sentiment. Gilts, Bunds and US Treasuries are all in the region of 1 ¾ to 2 points adrift as oil prices bounce and more Governments commit funds to help fight the economic impact of VOVID-19 alongside ongoing efforts to stop the outbreak reaching pandemic proportions, like Italy’s nationwide lock down. However, all is far from normal in the bond and financial markets as Russia pulls its regular weekly OFZ auction for Wednesday due to unstable conditions. Ahead, the more routine API inventory update for crude and other products.

GEOPOLITICS

Turkish Foreign Minister says the Russian S-400 defence systems are not an obstacle to deploying US patriot systems and reiterates that if Syria breaks the ceasefire they will retaliate. (Newswires) 

US reportedly began withdrawal of troops in Afghanistan as part of a peace deal with the Taliban and is to cut the number of forces in the country to about 8.6k from around 13.0k. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

A day of respite, consolidation and potential short covering in the energy markets following yesterday’s violent Saudi-induced sell-off. WTI front month futures found an overnight base at ~USD 30/bbl and Brent April contracts touched APAC lows of just under USD 33.50/bbl – ahead of Saudi-fuelled lows around USD 27.40/bbl and USD 31.45/bbl respectively. Prices could also be experiencing some underlying support from OPEC delegates downplaying the expanding rift between Saudi and Russia, as they noted it is too early to give up on the alliance. That being said, Saudi Aramco’s CEO stated that it will supply its customers with 12.3mln BPD of oil starting April 1st – a number higher than the touted step-by-step increase as per sources, which noted the Kingdom could raise output to 11mln BPD before ramping production. As such, energy futures came under belated pressure and have been pushed to session lows of USD 30.20/bbl for WTI and USD 35.00/bbl for Brent, but nonetheless remain in positive territory following the gap higher at the reopen of electronic trade. Prices then found mild reprieve amidst comments from the Russian Energy Minister as he noted Moscow does not rule out join action with OPEC, despite also noting that Russian companies may boost oil output by up to 300k BPD and has potential to increase by 500k BPD – in fitting with comments from Russia’s Rosneft yesterday. Novak also noted of the next joint meeting to take place in May/June; OPEC’s website has scheduled this for June 10th. Sources stated that Russian Energy Ministry has called a meeting with Russian oil companies for tomorrow which is expected to discuss future co-operation with OPEC. Elsewhere, it’s worth noting that the monthly EIA STEO has been delayed to tomorrow to incorporate the recent oil market events. Onto metals, spot gold remains under pressure amid the overall risk tone in the market and as the Buck recoups some of its recent losses, with the yellow metal still above 1650/oz but notably below the USD 1680/oz overnight high. Copper prices meanwhile rebound with a vengeance after the prior session’s aggressive downside amid the risk tone and APAC stimulus measures (specifically from Japan), with the red metal back on a 2.5/lb handle.

Saudi Aramco CEO said the Co. will supply customers with 12.3mln BPD in April. (Newswires) Note, yesterday reports noted this could be increased to over 10.0mln BPD with some reports of as much as 12.0mln BPD – from their current (Feb) production of 9.7mln BPD

Russia Energy Minister Novak says Russian companies may boost oil output by up to 300k BPD and has potential to increase by 500k BPD; after initial reaction, markets are now more balanced– next OPEC+ meeting will be planned for May/June. (Newswires) Subsequently, Saudi Energy Ministry state they do not see the point in holding such a meeting only to demonstrate failures in dealing with ongoing crisis. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Ministry has called a meeting with Russian oil Co's for tomorrow, expect the Energy Ministry to discuss future co-operation with OPEC, according to sources. (Newswires)

China may buy additional oil at cheaper prices for its strategic stockpile, but those purchases may be limited, top govt researcher Wang Yongzhong said, cited by SCMP. (Twitter)

CME raised crude oil NYMEX futures margins by 17.1% to USD 4100/contract from USD 3500/contract and raised RBOB gasoline futures margins by 12.2% to USD 4600/contract from USD 4100/contract. (Newswires)

Stoxx 600 movers largely reflect an inverse of yesterday. Oil giants Shell (+12.5%), Total (+9.0%) and BP (+8.5%) amongst the top gainers. On that front, Exane BNP remains of the view that cash dividends will continue to see support despite yesterday’s sharp sell-off in oil and energy names, with preferred names remaining BP, Total and Equinor. In terms of more micro-movers, Deutsche Post (+6.3%) shares are supported amid an increase in YY Q4 revenue and a reaffirmance of its 2022 guidance. Italian-listed Diasorin (+17.4%) rose to the top of the FTSE MIB as the Co. completed its studies regarding a launch of coronavirus tests by end-March.

FX

NOK/JPY - Still flanking the G10 ranks, but the Norwegian Krona is now in pole position and Yen at the back of the pack in contrast to Monday when oil prices were tanking and risk aversion rife. Eur/Nok has recoiled further from nigh on 11.0000 to sub-10.7550 at one stage and almost oblivious to significantly weaker than expected inflation data or a downbeat regional survey even before the full extent of the coronavirus contagion has been taken into consideration. Conversely, Usd/Jpy has rebounded from near 101.00 yesterday to just over 105.00 as broad sentiment stabilises alongside crude, despite more exchanges between Saudi Arabia and Russia on the supply front.

USD - The Dollar has benefited from the relative calm in financial markets, partly instilled by US pledges via President Trump and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin to unveil big fiscal support measures, which in turn have flipped Treasuries back into bear steepening mode and eroded some appeal from safer currency and other havens. Hence, the DXY has pared losses from yesterday’s new 94.650 ytd base and briefly topped 96.000 within a 96.006-95.199 range.

CHF/EUR/GBP/NZD/AUD - All softer vs the Greenback due to the aforementioned turnaround in mood from extreme depression, with the Franc below 0.9300 again, Euro sub-1.1400, Cable under 1.3100 and Antipodeans losing a degree of their yield appeal from 0.6600+ and 0.6350+ respectively overnight. The Aussie also had drops in NAB business conditions and confidence to digest, while the Kiwi is absorbing comments from RBNZ Governor Orr indicating that there is more room to reduce the OCR (to zero or even negative if needed) rather than resorting to unconventional policy easing.

CAD/SEK - The Loonie is deriving some comfort from oil finding a base (for the time being at least) between 1.3706-1.3608 extremes vs its US counterpart and the Swedish Crown has regrouped amidst more Riksbank guidance steering away from a reversal in the repo rate in favour of QE if it need to take emergency policy action. Eur/Sek hovering around 10.7200 from 10.8100+ earlier and like the Nok cross not unduly bothered about data (household consumption).

EM - Respite after the rout, and with the Rouble not just gleaning traction from Brent clawing back outsize declines, but also the CBR’s intervention to stop the Rub depreciating in line with other regional Central Banks and bodies attempting to stem the tide.

FIXED INCOME

Rather mixed UK auction results have not really altered the current trend of core debt unwinding more of Monday’s huge safe-haven gains and yield compression amidst long end outperformance in recognition of the general revival in risk sentiment. Gilts, Bunds and US Treasuries are all in the region of 1 ¾ to 2 points adrift as oil prices bounce and more Governments commit funds to help fight the economic impact of COVID-19 alongside ongoing efforts to stop the outbreak reaching pandemic proportions, like Italy’s nationwide lock down. However, all is far from normal in the bond and financial markets as Russia pulls its regular weekly OFZ auction for Wednesday due to unstable conditions. Ahead, the more routine API inventory update for crude and other products.

COMMODITIES

A day of respite, consolidation and potential short covering in the energy markets following yesterday’s violent Saudi-induced sell-off. WTI front month futures found an overnight base at ~USD 30/bbl and Brent April contracts touched APAC lows of just under USD 33.50/bbl – ahead of Saudi-fuelled lows around USD 27.40/bbl and USD 31.45/bbl respectively. Prices could also be experiencing some underlying support from OPEC delegates downplaying the expanding rift between Saudi and Russia, as they noted it is too early to give up on the alliance. That being said, Saudi Aramco’s CEO stated that it will supply its customers with 12.3mln BPD of oil starting April 1st – a number higher than the touted step-by-step increase as per sources, which noted the Kingdom could raise output to 11mln BPD before ramping production. As such, energy futures came under belated pressure and have been pushed to session lows of USD 30.20/bbl for WTI and USD 35.00/bbl for Brent, but nonetheless remain in positive territory following the gap higher at the reopen of electronic trade. Prices then found mild reprieve amidst comments from the Russian Energy Minister as he noted Moscow does not rule out join action with OPEC, despite also noting that Russian companies may boost oil output by up to 300k BPD and has potential to increase by 500k BPD – in fitting with comments from Russia’s Rosneft yesterday. Novak also noted of the next joint meeting to take place in May/June; OPEC’s website has scheduled this for June 10th. Sources stated that Russian Energy Ministry has called a meeting with Russian oil companies for tomorrow which is expected to discuss future co-operation with OPEC. Elsewhere, it’s worth noting that the monthly EIA STEO has been delayed to tomorrow to incorporate the recent oil market events. Onto metals, spot gold remains under pressure amid the overall risk tone in the market and as the Buck recoups some of its recent losses, with the yellow metal still above 1650/oz but notably below the USD 1680/oz overnight high. Copper prices meanwhile rebound with a vengeance after the prior session’s aggressive downside amid the risk tone and APAC stimulus measures (specifically from Japan), with the red metal back on a 2.5/lb handle.

content: A firmer rebound from worst levels in core counterparts ahead of the Liffe open helped UK bonds contain losses in the face of considerably less risk aversion and some stability in oil prices in particular. However, the 10 year debt future failed to breach 138.00 in early trade after resuming trade at 137.82 vs yesterday’s 138.64 settlement and has subsequently drifted down to a deeper 137.16 low as the FTSE and other EU bourses regroup amidst another uptick in the crude complex. Hence, a better concession for upcoming DMO issuance in the form of Gbp2.25 bn 2030 Gilts as cash yields clamber of Monday’s extremely depressed levels. Back to Liffe, 3 month contracts are also retracing and the strip is re-steepening within -1.5 to -6.5 tick parameters.

subject: Saudi Aramco CEO said the Co. will supply customers with 12.3mln BPD in April
reaction_details:
• No immediate move seen in WTI and Brent front-month contracts
  • In a delayed reaction, downside is seen in the contracts in which Brent May'20 decline USD 36.45/bbl to USD 35.60/bbl whilst WTI Apr'20 fell from USD 33.40/bbl to USD 32.50/bbl
analysis_details:
• This follows reports from sources over the weekend noted that Saudi Arabia will be boosting its output to above 10mln BPD from this month’s 9.7mln BPD as a response to the collapse of the OPEC+ alliance with Russia.
  • Saudi is said to have told market participants that it could raise output to as much as 12mln BPD, although sources stated that the initial increase is likely to total between 10-11mln BPD in April, with the final figure contingent on refiners’ response to price cuts.
  • Furthermore, the Kingdom slashed its official pricing for crude, with oil behemoth Aramco cutting its Asia prices for Arab Light crude and Medium crude by USD 6/bbl each, to discounts of USD 3.10/bbl and USD 4.05/bbl below the Middle East benchmark respectively. In a challenge to Russia, the company made the largest cut to northwest Europe of some USD 8/bbl in most grades – Russia sells a bulk of its Urals crude in the same region. Finally, Arab Light sales to Europe will be at a USD 10.25/bbl discount to Brent – levels not seen since at least May 2002.

However, there is a long way to go before declaring anything like a turnaround Tuesday for risk sentiment, as oil remains extremely volatile and paring recovery gains following a modest bounce relative to the huge declines registered in wake of Saudi Arabia firing its first salvo in the crude price war. Indeed, the 10 year German benchmark has clawed back almost all its overnight losses within a 177.55-175.41 range vs Monday’s 178.23 close and keeping a close eye on Italian BTPs, Spanish Bonos and French OATs that are underperforming on coronavirus considerations given more cases and contagion at present. Ahead, Italian ip, pan Eurozone employment and GDP data, but all likely to be shrugged off as the clock ticks down to the ECB policy meeting on Thursday.

Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

10th March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CDT recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly higher as markets began to pick up the pieces from the recent oil-triggered devastation after Saudi instigated an oil price war following the OPEC+ breakdown, which resulted to losses of over 7% among most major US indices for the worst performance on Wall St. since 2008. Nonetheless, US equity futures found some reprieve overnight despite briefly dipping into bear market territory with the rebound helped by hopes of policy action with President Trump set to discuss payroll tax relief with congress and to hold a press conference on economic measures to respond to the coronavirus which he suggested will be major steps, while Japanese is to submit a 2nd package of steps on coronavirus to parliament. ASX 200 (+3.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) gained in which the former shrugged off opening losses of around 4% led by the recovery in the energy and financials sectors, while the Japanese benchmark also nursed losses helped by favourable currency moves. Hang Seng (+1.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.4%) were initially indecisive after continued PBoC liquidity inaction but eventually surged following a further reduction in China’s additional coronavirus cases and President Xi’s visit to the Wuhan coronavirus epicentre for the first time since the outbreak which was seen to be symbolic of China’s progress in its battle against the epidemic. Finally, 10yr JGBs slipped below 155.00 as it tracked the pullback in USTs after the recent safe-haven surge and as equity markets stabilized, while prices were also pressured after weaker results at the 5yr JGB auction.

FTSE 100

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN) – ViiV Healthcare has presented long-term data from Phase III study which demonstrates efficacy and safety of cabotegravir and rilpivirine for the treatment of regimen in adults living with HIV-1. (Newswires)

Co. says three divisions are modestly affected by coronavirus. (Newswires) Co. has ~2.8% weighting in the DAX30.

(Newswires) Follows on from recommendations last week that President Trump blocks the deal due to security risks, although it is unclear as to what these securities are. Infineon has a 2.7% weighting in the DAX30. Co. is seen opening higher by over 10%.

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Co. says EBITDA was considerably below prior year due to falling steel prices and weaker demand. Co. anticipates a considerable increase in operating income for FY20. (Newswires)

Uniper (UN01 GY) – FY19 net EUR 6.44mln vs. Prev. EUR -442mln. Adj. EBIT EUR 863mln vs. Exp. EUR 840mln. Co. raises dividend pay-out proposals FY19 and now targets 28% increase vs. Prev. +18.5%. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Such an order may delay the certification flight for the Max which has been touted to occur in the next few weeks. (Times/WSJ) Airbus has a 5.7% weighting in the CAC 40 and ~3% weighting in the EuroStoxx 50. Boeing has a 6.8% weighting in the DJIA

Co. says following months will be more impacted given the expansion of the virus on other parts of the world and extension of capacity reduction. (Newswires)

PM Conte also said all public gatherings are to be banned and the nationwide closure of schools and universities country was extended to April 3rd. (Newswires)

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 10th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·       Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly higher as markets began to pick up the pieces from the recent oil-triggered devastation

·       DXY traded higher and rose back above the 95.00 level after rebounding from 18-month lows

·       Italy has extended its emergency coronavirus measures to the entire country; includes restrictions on travel and public gatherings

·       Commodities were mostly underpinned as risk assets recovered from the prior day’s sell-off, with WTI crude futures higher by nearly 8%

·       President Trump announced he is to hold a press conference today on economic measures to respond to the coronavirus

·       Looking ahead, highlights include Norges Bank Regional Network Report, Eurozone GDP, APIs, supply from the UK, and US

 

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE 

Mainland China reported 19 additional coronavirus cases and 17 additional deaths on March 9th vs. Prev. 40 additional cases and 22 additional deaths on March 8th, to bring the total number of cases in China to 80754 and death toll to 3136. (Newswires) Chinese President Xi arrived in Wuhan for the first time following the outbreak, while there were also reports that China’s Hubei province is to implement a health code system to start permitting people to travel within the province. (Newswires)

South Korea coronavirus cases increased by 131 to a total of 7513 and its death toll increased by 3 to a total of 54. (Newswires)

Italy’s total coronavirus cases rose to 9172 from 7375 and the death toll rose to 463 from 366, according to an official. Italian PM Conte announced they are adopting tougher measures to tackle coronavirus and that there will no longer be a red zone but instead the whole country will be under same condition in which movement will be restricted all over Italy. PM Conte also said all public gatherings are to be banned and the nationwide closure of schools and universities country was extended to April 3rd. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he will speak about possible payroll tax relief with Congress and is working with industries including airline and cruise ship industries. President Trump also announced he is to hold a press conference today on economic measures to respond to the coronavirus and suggested that economic steps will be major, while reports later suggested that the coronavirus aid package will leave out the travel industry for now but will include payroll tax cut and short-term paid sick leave. (Newswires)

Japanese Finance Minister Aso said the government is to announce a 2nd package of steps on coronavirus on Tuesday and that G7 agreed to take fiscal and monetary steps as appropriate. There were also later comments from PM Abe who confirmed he will submit an emergency measure package to parliament today and will implement what is needed without hesitation to respond to coronavirus situation, while the second emergency package will include steps related to jobs and small firms. (Newswires) 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly higher as markets began to pick up the pieces from the recent oil-triggered devastation, which resulted in losses of over 7% among most major US indices for the worst performance on Wall St. since 2008. Nonetheless, US equity futures found some reprieve overnight despite briefly dipping into bear market territory with the rebound helped by hopes of policy action with President Trump set to discuss payroll tax relief with congress and to hold a press conference on economic measures to respond to the coronavirus which he suggested will be major steps, while Japanese is to submit a 2nd package of steps on coronavirus to parliament. ASX 200 (+3.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) gained in which the former shrugged off opening losses of around 4% led by the recovery in the energy and financials sectors, while the Japanese benchmark also nursed losses helped by favourable currency moves. Hang Seng (+1.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.4%) were initially indecisive after continued PBoC liquidity inaction but eventually surged following a further reduction in China’s additional coronavirus cases and President Xi’s visit to the Wuhan coronavirus epicentre for the first time since the outbreak which was seen to be symbolic of China’s progress in its battle against the epidemic. Finally, 10yr JGBs slipped below 155.00 as it tracked the pullback in USTs after the recent safe-haven surge and as equity markets stabilized, while prices were also pressured after weaker results at the 5yr JGB auction.

 

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9389 vs. Exp. 6.9562 (Prev. 6.9260). (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position

 

Chinese CPI (Feb) Y/Y 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.2% (Prev. 5.4%). (Newswires)

Chinese PPI YY (Feb) -0.4% vs. Exp. -0.3% (Prev. 0.1%)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reiterated the UK remains in a contain phase, but added scientists think containment is extremely unlikely to work on its own and are making extensive preparation for a move to the delay phase. (Newswires)

Britain is set to table its plans for a Canada-style free trade agreement with the EU ahead of the next round of negotiations, according to the government. (Times)

Senior Conservative MPs are to back an amendment to end Huawei’s role in the UK’s 5G network; via an amendment to the Telecommunication Infrastructure bill, up to 30 Tory MPs are seen backing the bill. (BBC)

UK BRC Sales Like-For-Like (Feb) Y/Y -0.4% (Prev. 0.0%). (Newswires)

Barclaycard said UK consumer spending rose 2.2% Y/Y in Feb. vs. 3.9% Y/Y increase in January, while it added that coronavirus fears led to 28% of respondents avoiding the high street and other busy places. (Newswires)

Italy is reportedly planning to increase its 2020 budget deficit above 2.5% of GDP (Prev. 2.2%) to help against the coronavirus according to a government source, while it later announced it is mulling setting its deficit goal at 2.8% of its GDP. (Newswires)

 

Discussions between Turkish President Erdogan and the EU regarding a resolution to the ongoing refugee crisis ended without an agreement on Monday. (Newswires)

FX

DXY traded higher and rose back above the 95.00 level after rebounding from 18-month lows. This resurgence in the greenback translated to a further pullback in its transatlantic counterparts in which GBP/USD retreated to test support at 1.3050 and with EUR/USD dispirited after several failed attempts to break through resistance ahead of 1.1500 which later saw the single currency give up the 1.1400 handle. In terms of the latest coronavirus-related news from the continent, Italian PM Conte declared a nationwide lockdown and announced all public gatherings are to be banned, while the closure of schools and universities was extended to April 3rd. Elsewhere, USD/JPY nursed losses and approached the 105.00 handle on the improved risk tone and as BoJ officials reiterated they will not hesitate to take additional steps although the pair still has far to go after a 3-week slide brought on by the recent safe-haven currency flows, while antipodeans were uneventful with only mild pressure seen amid soft Australian Business Survey data, mixed Chinese inflation figures and a weaker CNY reference rate.

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Feb) -4 (Prev. -1). (Newswires) Australian NAB Business Conditions (Feb) 0 (Prev. 3)

RBNZ Governor Orr said they have not and still do not need to use alternative monetary policy instruments and they are fortunate to have time to prepare for alternative steps unlike other OECD countries, while he also commented that zero bound for rates is far from most likely outcome but cannot be ruled out and that steps being considered include forward guidance, negative rates and rate swaps. Furthermore, Orr suggested need to be considered and realistic as to how effective rate changes will be in buffering the economy and that they will continue to use conventional policy until it is exhausted such as when OCR reaches 0%. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly underpinned as risk assets recovered from the prior day’s sell-off, with WTI crude futures higher by nearly 8% to trade above the USD 33/bbl after prices found a platform at USD 30/bbl and with momentum spurred by the stabilization across global markets. In addition, there was some optimism from a delegate who suggested it was too early to give up hopes for an OPEC-Russia alliance, while focus for the complex shifts to the upcoming inventory reports and delayed EIA STEO. Elsewhere, gold prices were only marginally pressured despite the resurgence of the greenback and firm rebound in stock markets, while copper rallied in tandem with the improved risk appetite and firm gains in Chinese commodity prices including Dalian iron ore future which rallied over 5%.

US DOE delayed the release of its monthly Short-Term Energy Outlook by one day to Wednesday to incorporate the recent global oil market events. (Newswires)

It's still too early to "throw in the towel" on an OPEC-Russia alliance, according to a Delegate cited by S&P Global Platts. (Newswires)

CME raised crude oil NYMEX futures margins by 17.1% to USD 4100/contract from USD 3500/contract and raised RBOB gasoline futures margins by 12.2% to USD 4600/contract from USD 4100/contract. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS 

US official said Trump administration will soon issue an advisory warning anyone holding Iranian oil in violation of US sanctions and will soon also issue maritime advisory to target ships that turn off transponders to avoid sanctions. (Newswires)

US reportedly began withdrawal of troops in Afghanistan as part of a peace deal with the Taliban and is to cut the number of forces in the country to about 8.6k from around 13.0k. (Newswires)

 

US 

The chunky bid extended on Monday amid the risk aversion and oil price collapse. The curve exhibited further bull flattening alongside weaker inflation expectations and corporate credit concerns as oil prices tumbled further towards their all-time lows, equities were also hit strongly. In the overnight session the 30-year bond was bid as much as six points, with desks noting nobody on the other side of the trade. The rally saw all yields move beneath the 1% figure for the first time in history, and participants now move to the question of when the Fed will cut again rather than if. By settlement, 2-year yield had fallen 21bps while the 30-year had fallen by 38bps to 0.840%, but above its lows of 0.702%. US T-note futures (H0) settled 1 point 8 ticks higher at 139.09+.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia-Pac trades mixed as the region picks up the pieces from the oil-triggered devastation
content:
Asia equity markets are somewhat mixed as markets begin to pick up the pieces from the recent oil-triggered devastation after Saudi instigated an oil price war following the OPEC+ breakdown, which resulted to losses of over 7% among most major US indices for the worst performance on Wall St. since 2008. Nonetheless, US equity futures found some reprieve overnight despite briefly dipping into bear market territory with the rebound helped by hopes of measures as President Trump is set to discuss pay roll tax relief with congress and will hold a press conference on economic measures to respond to the coronavirus which he suggested will be major steps, while Japanese Finance Minister Aso said the government is to announce a 2nd package of steps on coronavirus on Tuesday afternoon and that the G7 agreed to take fiscal as well as monetary steps as appropriate. ASX 200 (+1.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.2%) are mixed in which the former shrugged off opening losses of around 4% led by the recovery in the energy sector, while the Japanese benchmark remains constrained by the recent currency flows. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) are indecisive after continued PBoC liquidity inaction and a further reduction in China’s additional coronavirus cases with price action relatively rangebound amid the market stabilization in the region.

In FX markets, the DXY trades higher and is back above the 95.00 level after rebounding from 18-month lows. This resurgence in the greenback has translated to a further pullback in its transatlantic counterparts in which GBP/USD retreated to test support at 1.3050 and with EUR/USD dispirited after several failed attempts to break through resistance ahead of 1.1500 and the single currency now struggles to hold above 1.1400. In terms of the latest coronavirus-related news from the continent, Italian PM Conte has declared a nationwide lockdown and announced all public gatherings are to be banned, while the closure of schools and universities all over the country was extended to April 3rd. Elsewhere, USD/JPY nursed losses to trade at the 103.00 handle as BoJ officials reiterate they will not hesitate to take additional steps although the pair still has far to go after a 3-week slide brought on by safe-haven currency flows, while antipodeans are uneventful with only mild pressure seen amid soft Australian Business Survey data, mixed Chinese inflation figures and a weaker CNY reference rate.

Finally, 10yr JGBs have slipped below 155.00 as it tracks the pullback in USTs after the recent safe-haven surge and as equity markets begin to stabilize, while demand has also been sapped with participants looking ahead to the 5yr JGB auction results due later.
